column1: Dinalupijan came from the festival rites of the Aetas commemorating the deity "Indianalo"
column2: the goddess of hunting and bountiful harvest. "Indianalo" was paired with the Sanskrit word "jann"
column3: meaning paradise. "Indianalopijann" was the name given to the land that the Aetas received from their goddess which translates to Indianalo's paradise. As time passed

column2: coming from the Spanish terms din
column4: and lupia. It referred to the fact that it failed to produce little revenue while it was an estate of the Archdiocese of Manila during the second half of the 18th century.

column1: Dinalupihan borders Hermosa to the south and southeast

column4: is located directly to the north
